doc.title: Authentication
doc.html:p: The DWOM Web Service's authentication scheme is based on several pieces of data passed by a client over a secure connection (using SSL) in the form of URI query parameters. The pieces of data are: an application identifier, a user identifier, a token, and finally a nonce. This section of the WADL will describe how these pieces of data are generated and used in conjunction with each other to successfully authenticate against the DWOM Web Service.

Application Identifier (app id) An app id is a client specific unique identifier. It is not unique per installation, but unique to a particular application. This is an assigned id, meaning a client cannot generate one w/out asking for one from the service, or by sending a request to C&T-DWOM-Support@360i.com.
User Identifier (user id) A user id is a user specific unique identifier. More specifically, it is a 360i employee email address that is registered as a user with the 360i Client Portal Application.

Application License / Shared Secret A application license, in the context of the DWOM API, can be considered a shared secret. It's a piece of data known only to the application client and the DWOM web service that it's authenticating against. It's unique to a particular client and user combination. This is an assigned value, meaning a client cannot generate one w/out asking for one from the service, or by sending a request to C&T-DWOM-Support@360i.com.

Token A token is a client generated value used to authenticate a particular request. A token is generated by using a sha1 hash (using the US Secure Hash Algorithm 1) of three pieces of data concatenated together in the following order: Application Identifier, User Identifier, and a Shared Secret.

Nonce Version 1.0 of the DWOM API will not use the nonce for anything other than to check for it's existence. The value can be anything; the only thing that matters is that it's present. It's put into place for future version compatibility.

Every request to the DWOM API requires authentication and should contain the following query parameters. If a request does not validate, a 401 Unauthorized HTTP status will be returned. All requests must be made over a secure connection SSL.
doc.html:h3: Requesting an Application Identifier and/or Application License
doc.html:p: When building a client and requesting a new application identifier, or when requesting a license for a user, please send a request to the following email address, C&T-DWOM-Support@360i.com.

This resource is the entry-point to the DWOM REST web service that exposes hypermedia links to all of the various resources available to a REST client. The DWOM web service subscribes to the HATEOAS constraint, which defines the principle saying that a client interacts with a network application entirely through hypermedia provided dynamically by application servers. Essentially, what this is saying is that a client can obtain everything it needs to know about navigation the web service simply by having access to this resource. For more information on HATEOAS see wikipedia.

An outlet is a web-based publication owned by some influencer. Typically, this is how an outlet fits into the DWOM workflow:

html:ul.html:li: An agent from the 360i DWOM team will obtain information relevant to a 360i client campaign.
Said agent will identify an outlet that can be used promote the information relevent to client campaign.
Agent will contact influencer about publishing the relevent information in hopes that the influencer will post it to one of their outlets (an influencer may have one or more outlets).

doc.html:div:
Types of outlets are:
Blog
Twitter
Profile
Web Site
Portal
Client Site
Forum
YouTube
